I laid down in the back of her van and cried the whole way home and asked her, â€œmom, how do you do it?â€ Through silent tears she said, â€œyou love your patients truly, but you learn to build a distance. She would have a drink on her nights off and drown in her silent despair. Cancer is so wrong and unfair on every level.   Unfortunately, my hero mother who saved countless lives of both adults and children is now a brain damaged triplegic due to strokes. They didnâ€™t believe her when she showed up at the hospital telling them (in her heavy accent), â€œI am having a stroke.â€ They let her brain die for 2 days until she went into a coma and needed emergency brain surgery. Her disabilities have bankrupted us both and I alone take care of her without an ounce of help. Just like cancer, human error and assumption can be just as deadly.   Life isnâ€™t fair. So sorry about losing your buddy Braxton last year.  This video just popped up in my feed. Braxton sounded like a lovely boy - cancer sucks!  My boy Jason was diagnosed when he was 7 with one of the more treatable forms of childhood cancer, Hodgkins Lymphoma, & went into remission after chemo & radiation treatments and received a grant from Make A Wish to go to Disney World in Florida.........he did not have any siblings to share the trip with so they told him to invite a friend & they covered the additional expense.  It's such a wonderful organization.  The boys had a wonderful & memorable experience.  Five years later the cancer returned with a less favorable prognosis but he pushed through. Children are so resilient in facing these battles but sadly, his immune system was destroyed by the intense treatment and he got an infection that took his life before the last scheduled treatment---he was so very close to remission again.  It's heart-breaking when a child dies, I know.  Yours & Braxton's story is very touching - thank you for sharing it. Nothing makes me sader then seeing a kid suffer
Nothing makes me cry like a baby more than when I see animals and children suffering and/or dying.  There's nothing more painfully sad and unfair than seeing the most innocent and loving among us, (animals and children) hurting.  Because there's nothing you can do to stop and prevent it, except just to be there with unconditional love kindness, which is exactly what you did for Braxton.  Try to find some peace and solace with the understanding that you did that for him, despite how painful it is for you now, so that he was able to forget about his struggles and just thoroughly enjoy the time he spent with you.  Braxton no longer is in pain, struggling, mortal, and fearing the unknown.  He's now living in total immortality and eternal joy and peace.  There is only love, with no more suffering...for Braxton.  For those left with his memory, their sadness but only because we selfishly can't see him again.  Yet he's now everywhere seeing everything and knowing how much he still is loved and will always be forever.  RIP little dude.  The world will never forget you buddy.

Rest in peace little braxton.  the Kicking butt with two T's part, that hit me man..
Dear Jake. Your heartfelt video touched my heart and hit very close to home. I started watching your videos because of my Son, Joshua. Joshua was 8 when he introduced me to your YouTube Channel. Joshua and I would sit and watch your videos and adventures together. In September 2017 at the age of 9, Joshua was diagnosed with Stage Four Neuroblastoma Cancer.  The diagnosis was something that came out of the blue and hit our family to its cure. From the very start Joshua would assure us he was going to be just fine. He said "God gave him this disease so another child didn't have to suffer with it". Neuroblastoma is typically a Cancer that effects much younger children and not children's Joshua's age, but in rare cases older children are diagnosed.  Joshua fought for 4 long years and underwent many rounds of chemotherapy,  immunotherapy, radiations, surgeries, experimental and study treatments, stem cell harvesting and transplants,  and so much more. Joshua and I spent many hours sitting and watching your videos. It was our special time together. Like Braxton, Joshua was also eligible for a Wish. Joshua wanted a pool because he loved swimming and wanted to learn to scuba drive.  Due to the Covid restrictions at the time we were unable to have Joshua's pool installed. Unfortunately Joshua passed away in December 2020, just 8 days after his 13 birthday. My heart goes out to Braxton's family because I know the heartache they are feeling and going through. As a parent we are never supposed to outlive our children.  The struggle of watching your child under go treatments and surgeries is heartbreaking. I would have taken my Son's place in a heartbeat. I love that you took such an interest in Braxton and made his wish come true. You made his dreams come true! You are such a special man, for so many reasons, but most of all your kindness and love for others shines through. My heart breaks for Braxton's family and those who loved him and were blessed to know him. I'm so sorry this comment was so very long. I wanted you to know, that although you don't know it, you were a part of many special memories my Son, Joshua, and I shared. You are and amazing young man with a heart of gold. My thoughts and prayers are with Braxton's family and all who knew, loved, and supported him through his journey. May Braxton rest in peace and fly high as the angel he is now.

R.I.P. Braxton
Make-A-Wish is an amazing charity.  My daughter has a brain tumor and was granted her wish to see the Eiffel Tower after she stabilized from her first procedure (craniotomy).  She has a deep fascination with monuments and statues.  While we have visited various monuments from coast to coast in USA, the Eiffel Tower is the pinnacle of monuments in her eyes.  Make-A-Wish made this wish a reality for her, along with many other historic monument visits in Paris.  Please consider donating to Make-A-Wish.  They truly do change lives, exemplify generosity, and most importantly, bring hope and a much needed smile to those who desperately need it.

God grants us just so many days, for Braxton it was time for him to be with the Lord, without pain and suffering! Let us rejoice that he was a part of our lives for the time he was here, the impact that he made and the love that he shared. As a retired PICU nurse, I understand the pain of loss felt. I had gone on vacation for ten days, returned to the PICU and was told that seven kids I had been a primary nurse with had passed duty the time I was gone. I so understand the tears, each of these children are an amazing blessing. For me, I tried to continue working in the PICU, but I was not strong enough emotionally and needed a break. I praise all the doctors, nurses and support staff who work with critically/terminally ill children. That work is the most demanding and yet rewarding work one can imagine. The families of the children are amazing, supportive and such a blessing. I thank God I had such an opportunity to work there. Braxton may you Rest In Peace forever more!

Rest in peace buddy and kick some butt with two t's up there! You better! â¤â¤
My father-in-law had a glioblastoma mulitform, the most aggressive type of cancer that begins with the brain. He was feeling really down in the dumps one day when he was getting fitted for a special radiation helmet, until he looked over and there on the shelf were a bunch of little tiny ones. They were for children! It was that day when he basically just told the doctors to learn from him. Use him to get closer to a cure. He was initially told he had a few months. He lasted 3 more years, entering a few studies along the way. The doctors didn't know how he was doing it, but we like to think that today some kids might live a little longer now. This is one of the many reasons I don't believe in the concept of a God. What kind of sick all powerful being would give children cancer? Science is the way to a cure. It's the only way we'll get there.
Im crying rn, may he Rest In Peaceâ¤ï¸

It's so hard to lose your child.  Even when you're prepared for it, it's still tough.   I lost two of my baby girls both 15 when they passed.  They had a rare genetic disease called Ataxia Telangiectasia.  They were diagnosed pretty early and they lived pretty hard lives in and out of doctors, months long hospital stays, poked, prodded, operated on.  My oldest had a skin infection for years until they had to amputate her knee.  She then got cancer and had to undergo chemo.  She passed first in 2019.  Her younger sister then passed in 2021.  Make a wish sent us to Disney World back in 2013 when they could still get around some.  We stayed at the Give the Kids the World village for a week and had the best time ever.  Their youngest sister just turned 15 yesterday and although she doesn't have the disease, she's a carrier and that will still impact her life as well.  If she has children they have a 50/50 chance of having the disease.  Her two older sisters are in heaven now with their perfect bodies and I'll bet anything they're showing Braxton around and having a blast together.  â¤ï¸ğŸ™

All of this makes me think about a poem that helps me with the people I have lost in my life.  When tomorrow starts without me by David Romano.  When tomorrow starts without me, And I'm not there to see, If the sun should rise and find your eyes all filled with tears for me, I wish so much you wouldn't cry The way you did today, While thinking of the many things, We didn't get to say. I know how much you love me, As much as I love you, and each time that you think of me, I know you'll miss me too. But when tomorrow starts without me, Please try to understand, That an angel came and called my name, And took me by the hand, And said my place was ready, In heaven far above, And that I'd have to leave behind All those I dearly love. But as I turned to walk away, A tear fell from my eye For all my life, I'd always thought, I didn't want to die. I had so much to live for, So much left yet to do, It seemed almost impossible, That I was leaving you. I thought of all the yesterdays The good ones and the bad, I thought of all the love we shared, and all the fun we had. If I could re-live yesterday Just even for a while, I'd say good-bye and kiss you And maybe see you smile. But then I fully realized, That this could never be, For emptiness and memories, would take the place of me. And when I thought of worldly things, I might miss come tomorrow, I thought of you, and when I did, My heart was filled with sorrow. But when I walked through heaven's gates, I felt so much at home When God looked down and smiled at me, From His great golden throne. He said, "This is eternity, And all I've promised you." Today your life on earth is past, But here life starts anew I promise no tomorrow, But today will always last, And since each day's the same way There's no longing for the past. You have been so faithful, So trusting and so true. Though there were times You did some things You knew you shouldn't do. But you have been forgiven And now at last you're free. So won't you come and take my hand And share my life with me? So when tomorrow starts without me, Don't think we're far apart, For every time you think of me, I'm right here, in your heart.

I'm so very sorry sir! What an amazing little boy and wonderful family!I'm I don't know you sir, but this popped up on my news feed and it was like I just needed to check out the video. I felt drawn to it. I'm so glad that I did. I would like to say to you that you were an inspiration for this precious child and you are a very special person. Not many people would be willing to put aside their own feelings for the benefit of someone else. It's just too hard in a situation like this. Most people would say" I'm sorry" or "I'm praying for you" and then move on. Those words are great but you went above and beyond, placing Braxton first as well as the family. You became an actual living, breathing and tangible gift. You gave to Braxton something that no one else could. He chose you and you literally gave yourself to him. Pure selflessness! What an awesome honor.  Also, may I say how much I appreciate you for being transparent and authentic in your genuine emotions and willingness to share something so difficult and personal to express is very humbling. Braxton will live on in the minds and heart's of many. Thousands who never met Braxton (me as an example) will be able to carry his spirit and share to countless others because of the generosity of his family to allow their child to be an example of what is the best  parts of life. Living each day with the fullness of our ability, strength, perservility, joy, laughter, peace even in the midst of a storm. Most of all Love. Unconditional! It's rare and hard to find! Braxton had it in spades for you! Through the innocence and unadulterated  pureness of a child he became the epitome of what real love is. If we as adults could learn something so wonderful and wise from a little boy our world would be much different. Perhaps we should observe/listen to the children more often! It certainly wouldn't hurt and we just might find the answers to some of life's most  asked questions or the key to many of the seemingly  unobtainable goals we as the so called more wise demographic haven't yet learned. Thank you sir for letting us see into your heart. Your vulnerability was raw yet refreshing. Hopefully each person who stumbles upon your video will be as touched as I am and Braxton's life will have a phenomenal effect on multitudes of people. An amazing legacy from such a beautiful soul and short life. How Incredible! How blessed are the people who knew him! And how blessed are we that have just now met him? We should all strive to have the amount of power in our lives that this young boy had in his little pinky. God Bless Braxton's Family and God Bless You Kind Sir! Sending love from South Georgia!â¤ï¸

Jake, you are one of the most amazing human beings. I want to thank you for so many things; the work you do cleaning up our rivers, lakes, and oceans, the message you spread of caring about our waterways and planet, the kindness that you show to everyone, but, most especially, the incredibly caring soul that you are. As the parent of a 2 time cancer survivor ( she fought Burkitts Lymphoma and Burkitts Leukemia and WON), I can tell you, without a doubt, that what you did for him did so much more for his heart and his family than any doctor or surgery or drug could ever have done. You literally took away his pain, suffering, and fear, even if only briefly. You gave him life back, even if it was only for a short time. You gave his family happy memories, of his last days, when otherwise they might not have been. They received so much comfort, and this will continue, from seeing him happy and smiling during an otherwise horrible time, and they will carry those Happy memories with them eternally. YOU are a Good Man, in a world where those are few and far between, please take comfort in that. And, Thank You, from the bottom of my heart, for all that you do. Stay safe and be at peace.

ğŸ•Š
You know it is very sad when a child passes away from an illness a disease. Cancer itself is a horrible horrible horrible illness to have. There are some children that are able to fight it and get through it and it's great. But for those who don't make it their families left the hole in her heart. That sometimes can and can't be repaired. The people that knew that child are going to miss him terribly. And they're left with this emptiness. And sometimes like I said it could be repaired. Sometimes those family members just get so depressed afterwards. But they forget who their child was I forget who they are. They have to try to live on in his memory. And they have to keep him alive in theirs. But the cool thing is. He's not in any more pain he's not suffering he's in heaven God's got him. And he's got a brand-new bodies got his little angel wings and he'll be fine. He's just watching over his family now washing over his friends. Waiting for them. Waiting for God to call them home. God takes people from us no Rhyme or Reason he just takes them. He takes them in his own time he takes them when he's ready for them to come home period death has a purpose without death there is no life without life There Is No Death. Sometimes things just have to happen now they happen. It's heartbreaking is sad it leaves a big hole in our hearts. But this happened death is part of life. I recently lost my aunt Pam to cancer. She was in the hospital room with strangers my Uncle Paul couldn't be with her while she died because of Corona. My aunt Pam died alone. She chose not to fight her cancer cuz she had it when she was younger. And she hated with the chemo did to her. And she swore she'd never put herself through it again. She had been suffering with cancer for quite some time but never let it keep her down. And God finally called her home. And she's in a better place. She's not in pain she's not hurting. So if my Uncle Paul all alone with a broken heart. But he'll see her again. It's never good-bye it's all see you later.

Rest In Peace, Braxton. There's nothing more innocent than a child trying to pull through a sickness. I know that it might be rough on you, Jake...but one thing that you can and should be proud of is that of all of the things that Braxton could have watched, he liked your channel so much. There's no telling how many ridiculous amounts of hours he has watched your videos - perhaps even every single one of them many times. Then he got to meet you and you made his day. He got his wish fulfilled very well. One of the greatest gifts that you can give a kid like this with limited time is what their ultimate wish is and you've done that. You also did it unknowingly because even during times when he undoubtedly didn't feel well, was getting treatments, etc., he would use your videos to experience the adventure that he could physically enjoy. You did it for him and recorded it and it was almost as much fun for him as being there. That made far more than just one of his days through the Make-A-Wish. The only other thing that you don't have to do, but are already doing, is continuing to raise money for other kids to also fulfill their dreams. Here's hoping that other Braxtons in the future also get to fulfill a similar wish through you. If your channel wasn't here and you weren't doing these things, then Braxton wouldn't have had an outlet to physically enjoy something vs watching cartoons or many of the other non-interactive things that boys his age typically are focused on. Now he's finding all kinds of good stuff on the other side. Maybe we can all have a treasure hunting party someday with Braxton. Can't wait, little buddy.

Rest In Peace Braxton
I'm so sorry to hear about Braxton. I understand your feelings. I had Lukima when I was (11-14) I was on of the older ones on the children's ward it was incredibly hard going thought that let alone watching all those younger children go through it, it was utterly heart breaking. You would often have long stays in the hospital and as Ireland is a small nation there was almost always two people a room on the ward. So you would often make have a room mate. I made good friends with a girl called Aiofe (Effa) she had a brain tumor and was 10 and we had a good bit in common. We would spend hours talking about having sleep over's when we got out and binge watch all the extended Lord of the rings movies with her favorite snack (Doritos!) , or debate who's dad snored the loudest as one parent would almost always stay the nights with us (her dad was the worst but I let her think it was mine as it made her so happy lol) We had so much fun planing what we would do when we got out of there.. A few months later I saw her at an event for children with caner. She was in a pram/ buggy at that stage and was so thin and pale and fail looking we still talked about what we would do when she was feeling better but you could tell that she had little energy left. I had thought she was just tired as the treatment can really take it out of you. Another few months later I was going into the ward to get meds and blood done. I ran into her mother and father. She had just passed on and they were finishing up on the ward with the staff. Her mom and dad thanked me for how much time I spent with her and effort I put into talking to her and for how happy I made her and joy I had brought them all and really helped her. At the time I was so numb I can only remember thinking.. But I didn't do anything, I was her friend..I only did what friends do, and we didn't even get to do what we planed, I shouldn't be thanked. My immune system was not good enough to go to her funeral and I never saw them again... It still hurt years later thinking on that amazing bubbly girl with buckets of personality and all we never got to do.. She was sadly one of many friends I lost in that period of time.  For what its worth I would say allow yourself to feel heal and processes. But also take joy form the fact that you got the privilege to know them and impact their life make them happy and they did the same for you. That in of itself is a gift we can often forget as we let the pain of what we think should have been take over. I am so great-full to Jesus who has healed me of the pain of the past and brought me through to the other side. I pray that he heals you and Braxton's family also form any hurt pain trauma and helps them to grieve in a way that would heal their souls and bless them. Knowing that he was a gift and that one day we will see them again in heaven as his children. My genuine condolences and prayers for you and especially Braxton's family, much Love  form Ireland <3
Made a grown man cry. Iâ€™m sure anyone who watched this did as well. Much love to the Braxton, his family and to you for sharing this touching story with us.  Youâ€™ve gained a life long follower in the form of a little angel. RIP Braxton

UPDATE 2/6/21: Braxton, I'm honored that you chose me for your Make-A-Wish. Your ceremony was absolutely beautiful buddy. Your family is so amazing. Everyone kept saying how I was your hero and how I positively affected your life, but you did that to me ten fold. You've inspired me to live the best life I can. You're family said green was your favorite color, so I wore green for you at your funeral. Save some treasure up in heaven for me! We miss you bud. Lets live our lives "Kicking Butt With Two T's" just like Braxton!   You can directly donate to Braxton's family with my link provided here: https://bit.ly/BraxtonWeidman  If you would like to take it to the next level feel free to donate to Make-A-Wish Foundation and help their amazing cause.
